subject: Gardening
title: Chemical Warfare in Plants
description: A quick, practical guide to Chemical Warfare in Plants.

hook.text: Poison ivy's urushiol causes agony in humansâ€”but the plant produces it specifically to deter mammals, not insects.

buildup.text: Plants produce thousands of secondary metabolites: alkaloids, tannins, phenolsâ€”each targeting specific threats.

discovery.text: Caffeine isn't for waking you up. It paralyzes and kills insects that try to eat coffee and tea leaves.

twist.text: At low doses, caffeine in flower nectar actually helps bees remember which flowers to revisit. The plant benefits twice.

climax.text: Plant chemistry is a pharmacy, a pesticide, and a pollinator manipulatorâ€”all produced by stationary organisms.

punchline.text: Your morning coffee is an insecticide to plants.

quiz.question: What dual role does caffeine play for the plants that produce it?
options: It fertilizes the soil and repels insects
It kills herbivorous insects and helps bees remember the plant's flowers
It attracts pollinators and poisons competing plants
